data.comments:
Need to get the docs in line to avoid net config issues in the future, and write a couple scripts.

Docs: Need to update docs to show the config of truffle for the demo, and the use of ethabi to decode and prove out that the data posted is in fact displayed on the blockchain in hashed and binary encoded format.

The two scripts: 

Post script should show peeling one event off a file of event lines, posting it, waiting for the post to complete, logging input data and the transaction ID.

Pull script should pull all contract events for that contract, using the etherscan API, and decode the data, demonstrating equality with the original data.  Basically take a transaction ID from the post_script log file, grabs the etherscan data, unencodes the etherscan data, and compares the post_script log file input data to the unencoded etherscan data.
data.stm_title: Fixup documentation on truffle commands - add scripts

stm_jfields.comments:
Need to get the docs in line to avoid net config issues in the future, and write a couple scripts.

Docs: Need to update docs to show the config of truffle for the demo, and the use of ethabi to decode and prove out that the data posted is in fact displayed on the blockchain in hashed and binary encoded format.

The two scripts: 

Post script should show peeling one event off a file of event lines, posting it, waiting for the post to complete, logging input data and the transaction ID.

Pull script should pull all contract events for that contract, using the etherscan API, and decode the data, demonstrating equality with the original data.  Basically take a transaction ID from the post_script log file, grabs the etherscan data, unencodes the etherscan data, and compares the post_script log file input data to the unencoded etherscan data.

data.comments: Peel one API event, hash, truffle exec using log_event.js - this is just a hacky way to prove out our infrastructure for testnet integration

stm_jfields.comments: Peel one API event, hash, truffle exec using log_event.js - this is just a hacky way to prove out our infrastructure for testnet integration

data.comments:
In the API, it might be handy to have a Transfer directive.

This could be especially useful in the situation where a trader holds multiple positions in a contract, and wishes to sell the positions as a single block.  Prior to sale, the trader could consolidate all positions into one using a Transfer directive.

stm_jfields.comments:

data.comments:
Feature idea: 

In addition to reselling a contract/position on the marketplace, we should allow users to transfer positions directly to specific users. 

This transfer can occur in exchange of money (tokens) or for free.

Transfers could be used to pay reviewers for their work or to pass on the contract after partial work to a trusted developer.
data.stm_title: Feature: transfer contracts/positions to other users

stm_jfields.comments:
Feature idea: 

In addition to reselling a contract/position on the marketplace, we should allow users to transfer positions directly to specific users. 

This transfer can occur in exchange of money (tokens) or for free.

Transfers could be used to pay reviewers for their work or to pass on the contract after partial work to a trusted developer.

data.comments: We need a free-text search capability.

stm_jfields.comments: We need a free-text search capability.

data.comments:
At some point we will need an "Embedded Frame" capability for people to drop a Bugmark frame into their own websites and customer-service systems.

Comparables: Discus, YouTube

The frame will contain: Issue Status, Current Price, Link to Bugmark Trading Interface

This is similar in purpose to the "GitHub Badge" feature that we have discussed.

stm_jfields.comments:
At some point we will need an "Embedded Frame" capability for people to drop a Bugmark frame into their own websites and customer-service systems.

data.comments:
We might want to add one step here where a user of the system determines whether s/he is interested in the FIXED or UNFIXED side of contracts. Consequently, the user interface (view) could be simplified for either side while allowing the user to switch the view at any time.

For example, an end user with an issue interested in sponsoring a fix might have no interest in buying or selling a FIXED side of a contract but only UNFIXED.

@georglink  | Yep. "Here" is on the first page or in the top level menu.

Low priority. First we want to get a system up and running.

Maybe implement as a subdomain per #51
data.stm_title: Special purpose interfaces exposing one side only

stm_jfields.comments:
We might want to add one step here where a user of the system determines whether s/he is interested in the FIXED or UNFIXED side of contracts. Consequently, the user interface (view) could be simplified for either side while allowing the user to switch the view at any time.

For example, an end user with an issue interested in sponsoring a fix might have no interest in buying or selling a FIXED side of a contract but only UNFIXED.

@georglink  | Yep. "Here" is on the first page or in the top level menu.

Low priority. First we want to get a system up and running.

Maybe implement as a subdomain per #51

data.comments:
We need subdomains - eg:
- docfix.issuemark.net
- admin.issuemark.net
- cybersecuritybonds.issuemark.net
- employquick.issuemark.net

Notes:
- each subdomain is a separate app
- apps are standalone systems - different languages, servers, organizations
- apps comply with a bugmark defined 'acceptance spec' (branding standards, etc.)
- bugmark provides a single-sign-on layer for all apps
- bugmark provides utility services: email, ...

stm_jfields.comments:

data.name: mozilla/bugmark-docs

jfields.readme_txt:
## Welcome to the Bugmark documentation

This repository is part of the [Trading futures, fixing bugs](https://github.com/MozillaFoundation/mozfest-program-2017/issues/414) demonstration at [Mozfest](https://mozillafestival.org/), October 27-29, 2017.

We will use a futures market, based on smart contracts, to develop some documentation.

Visit the BUGMARK SITE TK to get started.


## Table of contents

[About futures markets](/fixme/)


### Working with Jekyll

You can use the  [editor on GitHub](https://github.com/mozilla/bugmark-docs/edit/master/README.md) to maintain and preview the content for this site.  Whenever you commit to this repository, GitHub Pages will run [Jekyll](https://jekyllrb.com/) to rebuild the pages in your site, from the content in your Markdown files.

### Markdown basics

Markdown is a lightweight and easy-to-use syntax for styling your writing. It includes conventions for

```markdown
Syntax highlighted code block

# Header 1
## Header 2
### Header 3

- Bulleted
- List

1. Numbered
2. List

**Bold** and _Italic_ and `Code` text

[Link](url) and ![Image](src)
```

For more details see [GitHub Flavored Markdown](https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/).

### Support or Contact

Having trouble with Pages? Check out the [GitHub Pages documentation](https://help.github.com/categories/github-pages-basics/) or come see us at Mozfest.

## Welcome to the Bugmark documentation

This repository is part of the [Trading futures, fixing bugs](https://github.com/MozillaFoundation/mozfest-program-2017/issues/414) demonstration at [Mozfest](https://mozillafestival.org/), October 27-29, 2017.

We will use a futures market, based on smart contracts, to develop some documentation.

Visit the BUGMARK SITE TK to get started.


## Table of contents

[About futures markets](/fixme/)


### Working with Jekyll

You can use the  [editor on GitHub](https://github.com/mozilla/bugmark-docs/edit/master/README.md) to maintain and preview the content for this site.  Whenever you commit to this repository, GitHub Pages will run [Jekyll](https://jekyllrb.com/) to rebuild the pages in your site, from the content in your Markdown files.

### Markdown basics

Markdown is a lightweight and easy-to-use syntax for styling your writing. It includes conventions for

```markdown
Syntax highlighted code block

# Header 1
## Header 2
### Header 3

- Bulleted
- List

1. Numbered
2. List

**Bold** and _Italic_ and `Code` text

```

For more details see [GitHub Flavored Markdown](https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/).

### Support or Contact

Having trouble with Pages? Check out the [GitHub Pages documentation](https://help.github.com/categories/github-pages-basics/) or come see us at Mozfest.

data.comments: A section on the currencies that Bugmark can work with, including why real money cannot be used would be informative.

data.comments: A section on the challenges faced in developing the Bugmark platform would be useful. For example, we must deal with thinly traded contracts, possible gaming, etc.

stm_jfields.comments: A section on the challenges faced in developing the Bugmark platform would be useful. For example, we must deal with thinly traded contracts, possible gaming, etc.

data.comments: What are some applications of Bugmark other than bug fixing? Describe how Bugmark could help inform security researchers on the likelihood of vulnerabilities.

stm_jfields.comments: What are some applications of Bugmark other than bug fixing? Describe how Bugmark could help inform security researchers on the likelihood of vulnerabilities.

data.comments: Add a use case that describes a forecast type contract and one that does not involve an identified bug in a repository.

data.comments: An explanation of how Bugmark differs from a prediction market would be useful.

data.comments: Were there other contenders for the title? Are you open to suggestions? A section on possible title names for our platform would be fun.

stm_jfields.comments: Were there other contenders for the title? Are you open to suggestions? A section on possible title names for our platform would be fun.

data.comments: Bugmark is different from existing platforms in that it incentivizes partial work. An explanation of how traders using Bugmark can gain from doing partial work is needed.

stm_jfields.comments: Bugmark is different from existing platforms in that it incentivizes partial work. An explanation of how traders using Bugmark can gain from doing partial work is needed.

data.comments: A use case where a reward is offered to incentivize a fix for a bug identified in a repo would be useful.

stm_jfields.comments: A use case where a reward is offered to incentivize a fix for a bug identified in a repo would be useful.

data.comments: A section describing the research questions raised by Bugmark is needed.

stm_jfields.comments: A section describing the research questions raised by Bugmark is needed.

data.comments: Bugmark documentation should list and link to other existing market-based platforms (e.g., bug bounty, crowdsourcing, crowdfunding platforms) for software tasks.
data.stm_title: Links to other marketplaces for software tasks needed

stm_jfields.comments: Bugmark documentation should list and link to other existing market-based platforms (e.g., bug bounty, crowdsourcing, crowdfunding platforms) for software tasks.

stm_jfields.comments: Information on how to create and use oracles to work with Bugmark is needed.
